dataset.title: The Arctic Plant Aboveground Biomass Synthesis Dataset, Pan-Arctic, 1998-2022

abstract.para: Plant biomass is a fundamental ecosystem attribute that is sensitive to rapid climatic changes occurring in the Arctic. Nevertheless, measuring plant biomass in the Arctic is logistically challenging and resource intensive. Lack of accessible field data hinders efforts to understand the amount, composition, distribution, and changes in plant biomass in these northern ecosystems. Here, we present The Arctic Plant Aboveground Biomass Synthesis Dataset, which includes field measurements of lichen, bryophyte, herb, shrub, and/or tree aboveground biomass grams per meter squared (g/m^2) on 2327 sample plots in seven countries. We created the synthesis dataset by assembling and harmonizing 32 individual datasets. Aboveground biomass was primarily quantified by harvesting sample plots during mid- to late-summer, though tree and often tall shrub biomass were quantified using surveys and allometric models. Each biomass measurement is associated with metadata including sample date, location, method, data source, and other information. This unique dataset can be leveraged to monitor, map, and model plant biomass across the rapidly warming Arctic.

intellectualRights.para: This work is dedicated to the public domain under the Creative Commons Universal 1.0 Public Domain Dedication. To view a copy of this dedication, visit https://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Pan-Arctic, including the High Arctic, Low Arctic, Oroarctic, and Subarctic

taxonomicCoverage.generalTaxonomicCoverage: Vegetation was partitioned into five plant functional types: lichen, bryophyte, herb, shrub, and tree

section.title: Ethical Research Practices
section.para: This synthesis dataset includes field measurements of plant biomass that were derived from 32 individual dataset that various research teams collected across the Arctic. Each research team was responsible for following ethical research practices including obtaining research permits and permissions and ensuring the safety of team members. Authorship on the synthesis dataset was offered to all individuals who played a key role in collecting, processing, or managing the individual datasets.

description.para: To create the synthesis dataset, we assembled, harmonized, and screened individual datasets and then merged the harmonized datasets, added completeness flags, and performed further quality assurance. We harmonized plot-level plant biomass measurements and metadata from individual datasets using custom scripts written in R. Among other steps, we aggregated measurements of aboveground biomass into five plant functional types, including lichen, bryophyte, herb, shrub, and tree. We also harmonized sample dates, spatial coordinates, area, and method, and provide unique site and plot codes as well as a citation to each individual dataset. Further details are provided in the associated peer-reviewed Data Descriptor paper (Berner et al. 2024).
The synthesis dataset has measurements of plant aboveground biomass by functional type from 2327 sample plots.

Geographically, sample plots were located across seven of the eight Arctic nations and all bioclimatic zones. Most sample plots were from the USA (25%), Finland (25%) and Canada (20%), followed by Russia (16%), Sweden (6%), Greenland (6%), and Norway (2%). Currently, the synthesis dataset does not include sample plots from the Arctic nation of Iceland. In terms of bioclimatic zones, sample plots were located most often in the Oroarctic (39%), followed by the Low Arctic (32%), High Arctic (16%), and Subarctic (13%). Specific sampling locations were chosen based on the study deign of individual research projects.
Temporally, the synthesis dataset includes sample plots that were measured from 1998 to 2022. Most sample plots were measured once during mid- to late-summer in a single year.
Further details are provided in Berner et al. (2024).

samplingDescription.para: Plant aboveground biomass was quantified for most functional types by harvesting sample plots during mid- to late-summer. Typically, non-tree vascular plants rooted in a sample plot were clipped at the moss or ground surface and sorted into functional types (e.g., herbs, shrubs) or finer taxonomic groupings (e.g., species). If present, lichen and the green portion of mosses and other bryophytes were then harvested. Samples were dried to a constant weight typically at 50 – 60 Celsius (°C) using a drying oven and weighed using a digital scale. Trees and tall shrubs are challenging to harvest and process; therefore, tree and often tall shrub aboveground biomass were quantified on sample plots by (1) measuring the diameter of each stem at the ground surface or chest height, (2) predicting stem dry weight from stem diameter using allometric models, and (3) summing stem dry weight across all stems on the sample plot. For some sample plots, dwarf to low shrubs were harvested while tall shrubs were surveyed. The synthesis dataset includes the sampling date and quantification method for each plant biomass measurement.

Plant biomass is expressed as grams of oven-dried aboveground live biomass per square meter of ground surface (i.e., g/m^2); however, the actual area of each sample plot widely varied among individual datasets and plant functional types. For instance, bryophytes and lichens are small and particularly time consuming to harvest, thus sample plots typically were about 0.1 square meter (m2). In several cases, bryophyte and lichen biomass were upscaled using targeted harvests and measurements of functional type cover on a larger sample plot. Herbs and shrubs were typically harvested from sample plots that were about 0.25 m2, while tall shrub and tree biomass were quantified by surveying sample plots up to 25 m2 and 100 m2, respectively. The synthesis dataset therefore includes the area (m2) of the sample plot that was used when measuring plant biomass for each functional type.
Further details are provided in Berner et al. (2024).

dataTable.entityDescription: Aboveground biomass data by plant functional type for sample plots across the Arctic

codeDefinition.definition: Fungus engaged in mutualistic symbiosis with photosynthesizing algae and/or cyanobacteria
Non-vascular plants including mosses, liverworts, and hornworts

attribute.attributeDefinition: Aboveground biomass on sample plot in units of grams of oven-dried live biomass. Most users will likely want to focus on the attribute "biomass_density_gm2" which provides aboveground biomass in terms of gram per square meter.
Aboveground biomass on sample plot in units of grams of oven-dried live biomass per square meter of ground surface
